performance of Alluxio as a whole. This is especially
important if more than one path is being synced at a time.
It allows for a limited level of concurrency but still lets
us share a single thread pool for executing sync tasks.

+          .setDefaultValue(6)
+          .setDescription("The maximum number of concurrent sync tasks running for a given sync "

replies.bodyText:
Good question

MASTER_METADATA_SYNC_EXECUTOR_POOL_SIZE

This parameter determines exactly how many inodes can be processing sync in parallel.
The executor affected by this value is shared by all RPC calls to the master. So if you have 64 total threads in this executor, then a syncMetadata operation from a listStatus will compete for threads (submit tasks to the same executor) as a createDirectory RPC.



Now imagine you have a user who does a listStatus RPC that is high up in the inode tree, say, /dir1; but then another user comes along who wants to call getStatus on /dir2. It is mutually exclusive from /dir1, and may trigger a metadata sync, but if we allow listStatus on /dir1 to use all threads within this executor, concurrent sync operations could suffer in performance, even if /dir2 does not contain a large tree structure.

MASTER_METADATA_SYNC_CONCURRENCY_LEVEL restricts max #of threads a single RPC is allowed to use at any given time for processing an inode sync.

The reason that MASTER_METADATA_SYNC_UFS_PREFETCH_POOL_SIZE is separate is because in order to make progress during sync, ufs prefetch threads must be available, and so if all threads in MASTER_METADATA_SYNC_CONCURRENCY_LEVEL are taken and none can be used for ufs fetching, then we could run into a deadlock scenario. There is no limit per sync operation on how many threads can be used for prefetch. Though the throughput of requests to the prefetch pool is limited to an extent by the MASTER_METADATA_SYNC_CONCURRENCY_LEVEL

replies.bodyText:
How could it cause an endless cycle?
It only returns the previously submitted job for the given path. We have two options if there is already a prefetch job running on that path.

(current approach) Cancel the old one, submit the new one
Ignore the current request and rely on the future for the previously submitted future.

This path shouldn't really occur in the current code, but in the case it does happen I wanted to define the behavior. If the task is submitted later, I make the assumption that the user is submitting it because of some possible updated data in the UFS. The current prefetch job may already be executing or may be finished. I cancel it anyway in case it is running or about to run, and then submit the next one so whoever goes looking for the children later on will have a likely more up-to-date version of the UfsStatuses.
I don't see how this could cause an endless cycle?

timeline.bodyText: Does it matter if the oldest job finishes first or last? How would that affect behavior?
timeline.author: gpang

replies.bodyText:
I just take the oldest job submitted, because as long as the threadpool uses a fair queueing policy for running jobs, it has the highest probability of being completed before other jobs. If the oldest job runs slower, it can theoretically prevent other tasks from being submitted.
In a follow-up I'd actually like to design a ThreadPoolExecutor that doesn't need this control logic and can simply just iterate over the queue of pending paths and submit them. My idea is that the executor pool can be shared in a limited manner, so that you can lease out a portion of the threads. ex:
ExecutorService mainExecutor = Executors.newCachedThreadpool(64);

sharedExecutor = mainExecutor.lease(4); // executor service that uses the pool backing mainExecutor, that can have up to 4 tasks running concurrently.
sharedExecutor = mainExecutor.lease(32); // executor service that uses the pool backing mainExecutor, that can have up to 32 tasks running concurrently.
We can use a semaphore to block submitting tasks to the executor when they are already runing. Completely negates all the control logic of this thread. I haven't written the executor yet. This is all ideas yet. I don't plan on implementing it for this PR

timeline.bodyText: Is the general approach for RPCs to have a sync phase first, then the actual execution of the RPC? (Before it did the sync within the same contexts of the RPC execution).
timeline.author: gpang

replies.bodyText:
For All RPCs previously the sync phase typically came at the very beginning of the RPC after the initial permission check. This was the old way:

create RPC, audit context, lock inode path
check permissions
perform sync
perform RPC
unlock

Because of the new locking requirements, there is a new paradigm of

create RPC/audit context
check if sync is required

if so, lock properly for sync
check permissions
do sync
unlock from sync


lock for RPC
check permissions
perform RPC
unlock

The reason permission check is performed twice is because it requires having a locked inode path before doing the check.

timeline.message: Stop deadlock when caller already has a write lock
Appease findbugs and make parallelism configurable
Remove test assertion with runtime assumption
Shut down lock pool evictor threads

Make metrics heartbeat test always use localhost

Occasionally the JVM would pick up my computer's
LAN name rather than localhost which would cause this test to fail

Close FSMaster during tests

This prevents lots of un-closed resources from
accumulating while the test runs
Only use tryLock for sync stream

Fix LockPoolTest

I'm not sure how this test didn't fail more consistently before.

Previously, the test would insert values [0,15] into the lock pool.
Then, insert 16 in order to trigger an eviction. Next, it would finally
attempt to insert [16,23]. Which should go up to the high watermark.
However, sometimes the lock pool would evict entries [0, 8] (instead
of [0,7]) leaving [9, 16], and attempting to insert [16, 23]. [9,23] is
only 15 total entries, when it expects 16. I make the test now insert
[17,24]. It inserts the same amount of keys. It's just that the key
range is shifted, so that there is no key overlap.

The reason is because the evictor thread calculates numToEvict as
pool size - low watermark. After inserting the 17th item, the
numToEvict is 17 - 8 -> 9. For some reason before my changes,
this was being calculated as 8. As if the evictor was triggered prior
to the key being added.

Split sync executor size from sync concurrency

This can help limit the impact of a single sync job on the
performance of Alluxio as a whole. This is especially
important if more than one path is being synced at a time.
It allows for a limited level of concurrency but still lets
us share a single thread pool for executing sync tasks.

Use AlluxioURI for child index key

- Using the UfsStatus presents a few problems because of the possibility
of hash or equals collisions occurring because the UfsStatus object
doesn't compare the full path of the status, rather just the name
of that index. We don't lose anything by indexing using the full path
It is also guaranteed to not have collisions. It is strictly better.

UfsSyncIntegrationTest passes

Fixed FSMasterRestartIT, UfsSyncIT, PinIT, ReadOnlyMountIT

Fix unit and integration tests
Rethrow InterruptedException on status cache fetch
Rethrow InterruptedException on status cache fetch

Improve logging for sync and profiling

Utilized LogUtils.warnWithException to improve behavior of exception
logging.

Improve UfsStatusCache

- We always check for a prefetch job first before calling getChildren,
because a subsequent prefetch on the same path would then never get
removed.
- Added paths to some error log messages
- Increased test coverage on the class to 90%
